revision.text:
{{Infobox swimming pool | name = Gold Coast Aquatic Centre | caption = | address = Marine Parade, [[Southport, Queensland|Southport]], [[Queensland]] | postcode = 4215 | coordinates = {{coord|-27.963665|153.415854|type:landmark_region:AU|display=inline,title}} | opened = 1960s | closed = | demolished = | operator = | owner = City of Gold Coast | cost = | architect = | type = Public swimming pool | former_names = Southport Pool
Southport Olympic Pool | size = | length = | width = | depth = | status = Operating | features = The swimming and diving facility for the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games™. | facilities = Competition Pool
Diving Pool
Training Pool | website = {{URL|http://www.goldcoast.qld.gov.au/thegoldcoast/gold-coast-aquatic-centre-23174.html/}} | Phone = 07 5582 8282 }} The '''Gold Coast Aquatic Centre''' (also known as the Optus Aquatic Centre for the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games) is a public [[swimming pool]] complex located in the [[Southport Broadwater Parklands]] on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Queensland]].{{cite web |title=Gold Coast Aquatic Centre |url=http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/home.html |publisher=Gold Coast Aquatic Centre |accessdate=10 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115051958/http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/home.html |archivedate=15 January 2012 |df= }} It was the swimming and diving facility for the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]].{{cite news|last=Lacey|first=Michelle|title=Games bid a 'nail-biter', says Premier|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/05/363461_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=10 December 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=5 November 2011}} ==History== [[File:Gold Coast Aquatic Centre.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Gold Coast Aquatic Centre in 2015]] The ''Gold Coast Aquatic Centre'' opened in the 1960s as the ''Southport Pool''.{{cite web|title=Broadwater Parklands presentation booklet|url=http://www.gcparks.com.au/userfiles/file/BroadwaterParklands.pdf|publisher=Gold Coast Parks|accessdate=20 December 2011|year=2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202023412/http://www.gcparks.com.au/userfiles/file/BroadwaterParklands.pdf|archivedate=2 February 2012|df=}} The complex was renamed to the ''Gold Coast Aquatic Centre'' in the late 2000s. In 2018, the Gold Coast hosted the [[Commonwealth Games]].{{cite news|last=Ardern|first=Lucy|title=Coast wins 2018 Commonwealth Games|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/13/365241_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=10 December 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=13 November 2011}} The ''Gold Coast Aquatic Centre'' was the swimming and diving facility for the event. Approximately $40 million was spent on redeveloping the complex. The redevelopment included the construction of an additional 10-lane [[Olympic-size swimming pool|competition pool]], additional change rooms and new meeting rooms. Although the expansion was expected to be completed by 2017,{{cite news|last=Chambers|first=Geoff|title=Tweed region to share in Commonwealth Games windfall|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/tweed-region-to-share-in-commonwealth-games-windfall/story-e6frexni-1226199508611|accessdate=10 December 2011|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 November 2011}} the construction was brought forward to allow the venue to host the [[Pan Pacific Swimming Championships]] in 2014.{{cite news|last=Willoughby|first=Shannon|title=Coast to host Pan Pacs swimming in 2014|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/11/10/441574_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=10 November 2012|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=10 November 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111181622/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/11/10/441574_gold-coast-news.html|archivedate=11 November 2012|df=}} Work began on the redevelopment in March 2013.{{cite news|last=Ardern|first=Lucy|title=Call to start Carrara sports precinct plans|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/03/06/448186_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=6 March 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309040758/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/03/06/448186_gold-coast-news.html|archivedate=9 March 2013|df=}} The [[2014 Pan Pacific Swimming Championships]] were held at the Gold Coast Aquatic Centre and were headlined by all-time record holder for [[Olympic gold medal]]s [[Michael Phelps]] who won three gold medals.{{cite news|last=Pentony|first=Luke|title=Pan Pacs: Michael Phelps adds gold and silver to medal haul|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-08-26/pan-pacs3a-michael-phelps-adds-gold-and-silver-to-medal-haul/5696228|accessdate=27 August 2014|newspaper=ABC News|date=27 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140828021435/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-08-26/pan-pacs3a-michael-phelps-adds-gold-and-silver-to-medal-haul/5696228|archivedate=28 August 2014|df=}} ==Facilities== Prior to the 2014 major refurbishment of the Centre, the Gold Coast Aquatic Centre had a number of facilities. These including: * 50m x 21m wide Competition swimming pool - 8 lanes * 33m x 21m wide Diving pool * Diving platform located at various heights including 1m, 3m, 5m 7.5m 10m off the ground * 25m x 20m wide training pool - 8-lane During the 2014 refurbishment, additional water facilities were added as follows: * New 50m x 25m wide Olympic standard Competition swimming pool - 10 lanes * New 15m x 10m wide Indoor Learn To Swim pool * New Freeform Splash pool with water play features The refurbishment building design by Cox Rayner Architects has received the 2015 Queensland State Architecture Award for Public Architecture from the [[Australian Institute of Architects]].{{cite web|url =http://www.architecture.com.au/events/state-territory/queensland-chapter/queensland-awards/queensland-state-awards|title =2015 Queensland State Architecture Awards|last =|first =|date =|work =|publisher =Australian Institute of Architects|accessdate =6 July 2015|deadurl =no|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150706202534/http://www.architecture.com.au/events/state-territory/queensland-chapter/queensland-awards/queensland-state-awards|archivedate =6 July 2015|df =}} The refurbishment Aquatic design was Completed by Stevenson & Associates Pty Ltd. changes by Paul Stevenson of Stevenson & Associates ==Programs== A number of programs and classes are based at the ''Gold Coast Aquatic Centre''.{{cite web |title=Programs and Classes |url=http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/programs-and-classes.html |publisher=Gold Coast Aquatic Centre |accessdate=10 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116073429/http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/programs-and-classes.html |archivedate=16 January 2012 |df= }}{{cite web |title=Learn To Swim |url=http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/learn-to-swim.html |publisher=Gold Coast Aquatic Centre |accessdate=10 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116040019/http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/learn-to-swim.html |archivedate=16 January 2012 |df= }} These include: *Aqua Aerobics *Birthday Parties *Deep Water Running *Diving *Learn To Swim *Massage *Physiotherapy *Synchronzied Swimming *Underwater Hockey Additionally, Competitive, Masters, and Triathlon Squads are based at the complex.{{cite web |title=Squads |url=http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/squads.html |publisher=Gold Coast Aquatic Centre |accessdate=10 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116040038/http://www.goldcoastac.com.au/squads.html |archivedate=16 January 2012 |df= }} ==See also== {{Portal|Gold Coast|Queensland}} * [[Sports on the Gold Coast, Queensland]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.goldcoast.qld.gov.au/thegoldcoast/gold-coast-aquatic-centre-23174.html/}} {{Gold Coast Landmarks}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in the 1960s]] [[Category:2018 Commonwealth Games venues]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues on the Gold Coast, Queensland]] [[Category:Southport, Queensland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]] [[Category:Diving venues]]

[[File:Roger Connor (baseball player).jpg|thumb|right|[[Roger Connor]], circa 1887.]] In [[baseball]], a '''grand slam''' is a [[home run]] hit with [[bases loaded|all three bases occupied by baserunners]] ("bases loaded"), thereby scoring four [[run (baseball)|runs]]—the most possible in one play. According to ''The Dickson Baseball Dictionary'', the term originated in the card game of [[contract bridge]],{{better source|reason=Dickson does say that, but in fact the term was used in the original game of bridge, a.k.a. Biritch or Russian whist, about 40 years before it was developed into contract bridge. See History under Contract bridge, and the original rulebook in Wikisource. It would be correct to simply say bridge here, but that's not what the cited source says.|date=November 2016}} in which a ''grand slam'' involves taking all the possible tricks. The word ''slam'', by itself, usually is connected with a loud sound, particularly of a door being closed with excess force; thus, ''slamming the door'' on one's opponent(s), in addition to the bat slamming the ball into a home run.
==Notable highlights== [[Roger Connor]] is believed to have been the first major league player to hit a grand slam, on [[1881 in baseball|September 10, 1881]], for the [[Troy Trojans (MLB team)|Troy Trojans]]. Although [[Charlie Gould]] hit one for the [[History of the Boston Braves|Boston Red Stockings]] (now the Atlanta Braves) in the [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players|National Association]] (NA) on [[1871 in baseball|September 5, 1871]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballlibrary.com/chronology/byyear.php?year=1871#September |title=The Chronology – 1871 |last=Charlton |first=James |accessdate=2007-10-29 |publisher=BaseballLibrary.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017051521/http://www.baseballlibrary.com/chronology/byyear.php?year=1871 |archivedate=2007-10-17 |df= }}</ref> the [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players|NA]] is not recognized by [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] as a major league. [[File:Don Mattingly.JPG|thumb|right|In 1987 Don Mattingly set the record for most grand slams in a single season with six.]] [[Alex Rodriguez]] has 25 career grand slams, the most by any player in [[Major League Baseball]] history, passing [[Lou Gehrig]]'s 23 on September 20, 2013. [[Don Mattingly]] set the one-season record with six grand slams in {{Baseball year|1987}} – remarkably, the only grand slams of his major league career. [[Travis Hafner]] tied Mattingly's Major League record in {{Baseball year|2006}}, while in {{Baseball year|2009}}, [[Albert Pujols]] tied the one-season National League record of five grand slams set by [[Ernie Banks]] in {{Baseball year|1955}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/recbooks/rb_grsl.shtml|title=Grand Slam Records|author=|date=|website=www.baseball-almanac.com|accessdate=19 March 2018}}</ref>
Several grand slams, the first being Connor's in 1881, consisted of a player hitting a [[walk-off home run|walk-off grand slam]] for a one-run victory; some baseball observers call this an "ultimate grand slam".<ref name=SI>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/baseball/news/2002/05/17/ultimate_grand_slams |title=Ultimate Grand Slams|publisher=SI.com|date=2002-05-18|accessdate=2002-07-30}}</ref> [[Roberto Clemente]] is the only player to have hit a walk-off [[Inside-the-park home run|inside-the-park]] grand slam in a one-run victory;<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://armorypitching.com/grand-slam-baseball/|title=Grand Slam (baseball) {{!}} The ARMory Power Pitching Academy|website=armorypitching.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-11}}</ref> the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] defeated the [[Chicago Cubs]] 9–8 on [[1956 in baseball|July 25, 1956]] at [[Forbes Field]], a park known for its spacious outfield.
On April 10, 1980 – on [[Opening Day]], the [[Milwaukee Brewers]]' [[Sixto Lezcano]] hit a walk-off Grand Slam, reportedly the first such feat on an Opening Day. (Lezcano also has the distinction of hitting a Grand Slam the previous year, also on Opening Day.)
During the {{Baseball year|2005}} major league season, grand slams accounted for 132 of the 5017 home runs hit (2.6%). On June 13–14, {{Baseball year|2006}}, the [[Minnesota Twins]] hit grand slams in consecutive games against the [[Boston Red Sox]], including a [[walk-off home run|walk-off]] grand slam by [[Jason Kubel]] in the 12th inning on June 13.
In {{Baseball year|2006}}, the [[Chicago White Sox]] hit grand slams in three consecutive games against the [[Houston Astros]] (June 23–25). Scott Podsednik hit the only grand slam of his career in the series opener. Joe Crede followed up with a slam of his own on Saturday, and Tadahito Iguchi hit a game tying grand slam in the bottom of the ninth with two outs in the series finale. (This followed a three run blast by Iguchi in the bottom of the eighth.) The White Sox became the first team to accomplish this since the [[Detroit Tigers]] in {{Baseball year|1993}}. On the other hand, the {{Baseball year|2007}} [[Kansas City Royals]] surrendered grand slams in three straight games; two against the [[Baltimore Orioles]] (April 13–14) and one against the Tigers (April 16).
Also in 2006, [[Travis Hafner]] of the [[Cleveland Indians]] set a major league record by hitting five grand slams prior to the All-Star break, on his way to tying Mattingly for one season (his sixth was on August 13.) On July 16, [[Carlos Beltrán]] and [[Cliff Floyd]] of the [[New York Mets]] hit grand slams during an 11-run sixth inning against the [[Chicago Cubs]], marking the eighth time two grand slams were hit in a team's at-bat (the fourth time in National League history).
Four players hit a grand slam in their first Major League at-bat: [[Bill Duggleby]] ({{Baseball year|1898}}), [[Jeremy Hermida]] ({{Baseball year|2005}}), [[Kevin Kouzmanoff]] ({{Baseball year|2006}}), and [[Daniel Nava]] ({{Baseball year|2011}}). Kouzmanoff, Nava, and Duggleby hit theirs on the first pitch; Hermida's grand slam was in a [[pinch-hit]] [[at bat]]. [[File:Fernando Tatis.jpg|thumb|right|Fernando Tatís (pictured with the Mets) is the only player to hit two grand slams in the same inning, with the Cardinals, in 1999.]] [[Tony Cloninger]] is the only pitcher to hit two grand slams in one game, for the [[Atlanta Braves]] in a {{Baseball year|1966}} contest against the [[San Francisco Giants]].
[[Félix Hernández]] of the [[Seattle Mariners]] became the first American League pitcher since the [[designated hitter]] rule went into effect in {{Baseball year|1973}} to hit a grand slam when he did so on June 23, [[2008 in baseball|2008]], off New York Mets ace [[Johan Santana]] in an interleague game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2008013961_marinotes24.html |title=Notebook – Grand slam by Felix Hernandez is one for the books |accessdate=2008-12-30 |work=The Seattle Times |first=Larry |last=Stone |date=June 24, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906222415/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2008013961_marinotes24.html |archivedate=September 6, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
The only major leaguer to hit two grand slams in one inning is [[Fernando Tatís]] of the [[St. Louis Cardinals]], on [[1999 in baseball|April 23, 1999]] at Dodger Stadium, with both grand slams coming off Los Angeles' [[Chan Ho Park]] in the third inning. Tatis was only the second National League player to hit two grand slams in one game, joining Cloninger. Park was only the second pitcher in major league history to give up two grand slams in one inning; [[Bill Phillips (pitcher)|Bill Phillips]] of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] did it on [[1890 in baseball|August 16, 1890]], one to [[Tom Burns (baseball)|Tom Burns]] and one to [[Malachi Kittridge]], but Park was the first to give up both to the same batter. Tatis had never hit a grand slam before in his career. [[Bill Mueller]] is the only player to hit grand slams from both sides of the plate in the same game, when he hit 2 on [[2003 in baseball|July 29, 2003]] for the [[Boston Red Sox]] vs. the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]]. [[Robin Ventura]] is the only player to hit a grand slam in both games of a doubleheader, when he did so on [[1999 in baseball|May 20, 1999]] for the [[New York Mets]] against the [[Milwaukee Brewers]].
In [[Nippon Professional Baseball|Japan's professional league]], the feat of multiple grand slams in a single inning by a team has been accomplished three times; most recently on [[2007 in baseball|April 1, 2007]] by [[José Fernández (third baseman)|José Fernández]] and [[Takeshi Yamasaki]] of the [[Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles]]. The [[Daiei Hawks]] accomplished the feat in {{Baseball year|1999}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/sports/20070402TDY24002.htm|title=Hawks pound Shimizu, Marines|accessdate=2007-04-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
On August 25, 2011, the [[New York Yankees]], hosting the [[Oakland A's]], became the first team in MLB history to hit three grand slams in one game. [[Robinson Canó]], [[Russell Martin]] and [[Curtis Granderson]] took pitchers [[Rich Harden]], [[Fautino de los Santos]], and [[Bruce Billings]] deep, with each grand slam being hit in a different inning. Coming back from a 7–1 deficit, the second grand slam gave the Yankees their first lead of the game; they went on to win 22–9.<ref>{{cite news|author=Caldwell, Dave|title=On a Long and Wet Day, the Yankees Win in Grand Style|date=August 25, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/26/sports/baseball/yankees-win-in-grand-style-on-a-long-and-wet-day.html|work=The New York Times}} and {{cite news|author=Mouat, Mike|title=Yankees slam Athletics in grand fashion|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/26/us-baseball-yankees-slams-idUSTRE77P0FX20110826|date=August 25, 2011|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Slusser, Susan|authorlink=Susan Slusser|title=Yankees hit 3 grand slams to beat A's 22–9|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/08/25/SPQQ1KRV9D.DTL|date=August 25, 2011|work=San Francisco Chronicle|publisher=Hearst|accessdate=August 25, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Parker, Rob|title=It was a grand ole day at the ballpark|url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/mlb/story/_/id/6896894/new-york-yankees-set-record-grand-day-bronx|date=August 25, 2011|work=ESPN|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|accessdate=August 25, 2011}}</ref>
On July 13, 2014, [[Buster Posey]] and [[battery (baseball)|batterymate]] [[Madison Bumgarner]] of the [[San Francisco Giants]] hit grand slams against the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]]. It marked the first time in Major League Baseball history that batterymates hit grand slams in the same game.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pavlovic|first1=Alex|title=Giants' battery of Bumgarner, Posey provide charge heading to All-Star break|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/giants/ci_26142051/giants-battery-bumgarner-posey-provide-charge-heading-all|publisher=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref>
On June 3, 2017, a record-breaking seven grand slams were hit on one day: one each for the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]], [[Atlanta Braves]], [[Colorado Rockies]], [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Seattle Mariners]], and most notably, by the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]] whose [[Albert Pujols]] hit his 600th career home run.
==Walk-off grand slams== A player on the home team that hits a grand slam in the ninth or subsequent inning, which [[Walk-off home run|wins his team the game]], is known as a ''Walk-off grand slam''.
Starting in the 1990s, a walk-off grand slam that erases a three-run deficit has come to be known as an '''ultimate grand slam'''.<ref>Krabbenhoft, Herm. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LNBKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qukMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5856%2C1155716 "Dramatic finishes: Ultimate grand slams have decided 19 major league games"]. ''The Schenectady Gazette''. October 5, 1991. Retrieved 4 September 2015.</ref><ref>Amedio, Steve. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mHshAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H4oFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5132%2C4053024 "Krabbenhoft helps rewrite baseball records"]. ''The Schenectady Gazette''. April 18, 2003. Retrieved 4 September 2015.</ref><ref>Chuck, Bill; Kaplan, Jim (2007). [https://books.google.com/books?id=EX2iPhcpza0C&pg=PA193&dq=%22Ultimate+grand+slam%22+baseball&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCQQ6AEwA2oVChMI9PaDqYjexwIVxjw-Ch3X_gWg#v=onepage&q=%22Ultimate%20grand%20slam%22%20baseball&f=false ''Walkoffs, Last Licks and Final Outs: Baseball's Grand (and Not-so-grand) Finales'']. Skokie, Illinois: ACTA Sports. p. 193. {{ISBN|978-0-87946-342-7}}. Retrieved 4 September 2015.</ref> There have been 30 such instances documented in major league history – all taking place during the regular season,<ref name=MLB:UHR>[http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/rare_feats/index.jsp?feature=ultimate_slam "History of the Game; Doubleday to Present Day: Ultimate Grand Slams"]. MLB.com. Retrieved 4 September 2015.</ref> 15 of those coming with two outs.<ref>Jackson, Frank. [http://www.hardballtimes.com/ultimate-slam-game-over/ "Ultimate slam: game over"]. Hardball Times. September 11, 2013. Retrieved 4 September 2015. "No. 6: 09/11/1955, County Stadium. Hitter: Del Crandall. Pitcher: Herm Wehmeier. Braves 5, Phils 4. This was the first (of 15) ultimate slams with two outs, which would seem to make it a little more special than its predecessors."</ref> Of the 30 home runs, only [[Roberto Clemente]]'s was hit [[inside-the-park home run|inside the park]], at spacious [[Forbes Field]] on July 25, 1956.{{efn| The source for this frequently cited [[Factoid#Usage|factoid]] is Madison McEntire's 2006 book, ''Big League Trivia; Facts, Figures, Oddities, and Coincidences from our National Pastime''. (Indeed, as late as July 23 of that year, two days prior to the home run's 50th anniversary, an eyewitness account written by Pittsburgh-based sportswriter [[John Steigerwald]] stated merely that it "''may'' have been done only once in the history of baseball."<ref name=RCUHRbyJS>Steigerwald, John. [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/33551801/ "This Was Clemente's Grandest Slam"]. ''The Indiana Gazette''. July 23, 2006. Retrieved 4 September 2015. "On July 25, 1956, Roberto Clemente did something that may have been done only once in the history of baseball. And I was there to see it. "</ref> [Emphasis added.]) However, the claim, as it appears on page 53, and has since been repeated extensively, in print and online (i.e. "Clemente is the ''only'' player to end a game with an inside-the-park grand slam."), is actually qualified (along with most of the book's items) by McEntire in the book's introduction. "Unless stated otherwise, I used the year 1900 – the beginning of the modern baseball era – as the starting point for the items in this book."<ref>McEntire, Madison. ''Big League Trivia; Facts, Figures, Oddities, and Coincidences from our National Pastime''. Bloomington, Indiana: AuthorHouse. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qCnZVMfGuTsC&pg=PP11&dq=%22Unless+stated+otherwise,+I+used+the+year+1900%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAGoVChMI6Ki2orzdxwIViHM-Ch26Sg1F#v=onepage&q=%22Unless%20stated%20otherwise%2C%20I%20used%20the%20year%201900%22&f=false IX] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=qCnZVMfGuTsC&pg=PA53&dq=%22Clemente+is+the+only+player%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAGoVChMIyZiK0L3dxwIVw3U-Ch2Eeg91#v=onepage&q=%22Clemente%20is%20the%20only%20player%22&f=false 53]. {{ISBN|1-4259-1292-3}}. Retrieved 4 September 2015.</ref>}} [[Pittsburgh Pirates|Pirates]] manager/third base coach [[Bobby Bragan]] instructed him to stop at third, but Clemente ran through the stop sign to score the winning run.<ref>Hernon, Jack. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4pVRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=32oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6290%2C1323281 "Clemente's Inside-Park Slam Nips Cubs, 9–8; Bucs Bounce Back After Losing Lead"]. ''The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''. July 26, 1956. Retrieved 6 April 2015.</ref> [[Del Crandall]]'s September 11, 1955, [[Alan Trammell]]'s June 21, 1988,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET198806210.shtml|title= New York Yankees at Detroit Tigers Box Score, June 21, 1988|work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=June 22, 2018}}</ref> and [[Chris Hoiles]]' May 17, 1996 grand slams occurred under the [[cliché]] situation: bases loaded, two outs, full count, bottom of the ninth inning, and down by three runs. The most recent ultimate grand slam was hit by Chicago Cubs' infielder David Bote on August 12, 2018.
Three players have hit two walk-off grand slams in a season, [[Cy Williams]] in 1926, [[Jim Presley]] in 1986, and [[Steve Pearce (baseball)|Steve Pearce]] in 2017. Pearce's first was on July 27 (an 8–4 victory over the [[Oakland Athletics]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/244772520/steve-pearce-hits-walk-off-slam-for-blue-jays/?game_pk=491625|title=Pearce hits walk-off slam as Toronto sweeps A's|last1=Chisholm|first1=Gregor|last2=Lee|first2=Jane|work=MLB.com|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}</ref> followed by his second on July 30 (an ultimate grand slam, for an 11–10 win over the [[Los Angeles Angels]]), becoming the first player in MLB history to hit multiple walk-off grand slams within the span of a single week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article/245332662/torontos-steve-pearce-is-hero-again-with-slam/?topicId=27118412|title=Deja Blue Jay: Pearce's historic slam|last1=Matheson|first1=Keegan|last2=Guardado|first2=Maria|work=MLB.com|date=July 30, 2017|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/sports/article164465507.html|title=Pearce slams again, Jays score 7 in 9th, beat Angels 11–10|last=Harrison|first=Ian|work=ledger-enquirer.com|date=July 30, 2017|accessdate=July 30, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731043631/http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/sports/article164465507.html|archive-date=2017-07-31|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Only five pitchers in major league history have surrendered two game-ending grand slam home runs in one season, according to the [[Elias Sports Bureau]]: * [[Satchel Paige]] of the [[St. Louis Browns]], in {{Baseball year|1952}}, to [[Sammy White (baseball)|Sammy White]] of the [[Boston Red Sox]] on June 30, and to [[Eddie Joost]] of the [[Philadelphia Athletics]] on July 15. * [[Lindy McDaniel]] of the [[Chicago Cubs]], in {{Baseball year|1963}}, to [[Bob Aspromonte]] of the [[Houston Colt .45s]] on June 11, and to [[Jim Hickman (1960s outfielder)|Jim Hickman]] of the [[New York Mets]] on August 9. * [[Lee Smith (baseball)|Lee Smith]] of the [[California Angels]], in {{Baseball year|1995}}, to [[Mark McGwire]] of the [[Oakland Athletics]], on June 30, and to [[Albert Belle]] of the [[Cleveland Indians]] on July 18. * [[Francisco Rodríguez (Venezuelan pitcher)|Francisco Rodríguez]] of the [[New York Mets]], in {{Baseball year|2009}}, to [[rookie]]s [[Everth Cabrera]] of the [[San Diego Padres]], on August 7, and [[Justin Maxwell]] of the [[Washington Nationals]] on September 30. Rodríguez is the only pitcher to surrender two game-winning grand slams to two rookies. * [[Bud Norris]] of the [[Los Angeles Angels]], in {{Baseball year|2017}}, to [[Edwin Encarnación]] of the [[Cleveland Indians]], on July 25, and [[Steve Pearce (baseball)|Steve Pearce]] of the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] on July 30. Norris surrendered both in the same week, and it was the second game-winning walk-off grand slam by Pearce in the same week.
==Notable calls== "Get out the rye bread and mustard, Grandma, it is grand salami time!"- used by longtime [[Seattle Mariners]] lead commentator [[Dave Niehaus]] from the 1995 season until his death in November 2010.<ref name="Audio: Relive Some Of Dave Niehaus' Best Calls">{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/mlb/2010/11/11/1807248/dave-niehaus-death-memories-calls-audio-seattle-mariners/| title=Audio: Relive Some Of Dave Niehaus' Best Calls|publisher=SBNation.com|date=2010-11-11|accessdate=2015-06-20}}</ref> Currently used by Niehaus' longtime partner [[Rick Rizzs]].
However, archives have surfaced showing [[Milwaukee Brewers]] longtime announcer [[Bob Uecker]] using the term "Grand Salami" back in 1982, when the offense-tending team were dubbed "Harvey's Wallbangers" (a reference to manager [[Harvey Kuenn]], and a takeoff of the cocktail [[Harvey Wallbanger]]).

He comes through with the first [[walk-off home run|walk-off]] grand slam – and the first grand slam in extra innings – in postseason history, clearing the right-center field wall, but is officially credited with only a 1-run single after being mobbed by teammates upon passing first base. |- | [[2003 National League Championship Series|2003 NLCS]] | Game 4, October 11 | [[Aramis Ramírez]], [[Chicago Cubs|Chicago]] | [[Pro Player Stadium]] | [[Dontrelle Willis]], [[Florida Marlins|Florida]] | align="center" | 1st | align="center" | 4–0 | align="center" | 8–3, W | align="center" | 3–1 CHC | After Willis walks the bases loaded with one out, Ramírez gets the Cubs off to an early lead by hitting a 2–2 pitch into the left field seats. he homers again in the 4th for an 8–1 lead as the Red Sox complete their comeback after being down 3 games to 0. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2005 National League Division Series|2005 NLDS]] | Game 1, October 4 | [[Reggie Sanders (outfielder)|Reggie Sanders]], [[St. Louis Cardinals|St. Louis]] | [[Busch Stadium II|Busch Stadium]] | [[Jake Peavy]], [[San Diego Padres|San Diego]] | align="center" | 5th | align="center" | 8–0 | align="center" | 8–5, W | align="center" | 1–0 STL | With one out, Sanders homers on a 3–0 fastball from Peavy, who was unknowingly pitching with a fractured rib. |- | [[2005 National League Division Series|2005 NLDS]] | Game 4, October 9 | [[Adam LaRoche]], [[Atlanta Braves|Atlanta]] | [[Minute Maid Park]] | [[Brandon Backe]], [[Houston Astros|Houston]] | align="center" | 3rd | align="center" | 4–0 | align="center" | 7–6, L | align="center" | 3–1 HOU | LaRoche, battling stomach flu, homers with two out, after two walks and a hit batter, to give the Braves an early lead, but the Astros tie the game 6–6 in the 9th and win in 18 innings to advance to the NLCS. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2005 National League Division Series|2005 NLDS]] | Game 4, October 9 | [[Lance Berkman]], [[Houston Astros|Houston]] | [[Minute Maid Park]] | [[Kyle Farnsworth]], [[Atlanta Braves|Atlanta]] | align="center" | 8th | align="center" | 5–6 | align="center" | 7–6, W | align="center" | 3–1 HOU | With one out, Berkman hits an opposite-field homer to left on a 2–1 pitch to bring the Astros within a run; it is the first time that two grand slams are hit in the same postseason game. After tying the game in the 9th, the Astros win the series on [[Chris Burke (baseball)|Chris Burke]]'s walk-off homer in the 18th, making it the second longest game in postseason history. |- | [[2007 National League Division Series|2007 NLDS]] | Game 2, October 4 | [[Kaz Matsui]], [[Colorado Rockies]] | [[Citizens Bank Park]] | [[Kyle Lohse]], [[Philadelphia Phillies]] | align="center" | 4th | align="center" | 6–3 | align="center" | 10–5, W | align="center" | 2–0 COL | Matsui's slam gives the Rockies a 6–3 lead on the way to winning the game 10–5 and giving Colorado a 2–0 series lead. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2007 American League Championship Series|2007 ALCS]] | Game 6, October 20 | [[J. D. Drew]], [[Boston Red Sox]] | [[Fenway Park]] | [[Fausto Carmona]], [[Cleveland Indians]] | align="center" | 1st | align="center" | 4–0 | align="center" | 12–2 W | align="center" | 3–3 | Drew gave the Red Sox an early lead in the must-win game as the Red Sox tied the series. |- | [[2008 National League Division Series|2008 NLDS]] | Game 1, October 1 | [[James Loney (baseball)|James Loney]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | [[Wrigley Field]] | [[Ryan Dempster]], [[Chicago Cubs]] | align="center" | 5th | align="center" | 4–2 | align="center" | 7–2, W | align="center" | 1–0 LAD | After Dempster walked the bases loaded, Loney hits it to center to give the Dodgers a 4–2 lead. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2008 National League Division Series|2008 NLDS]] | Game 2, October 2 | [[Shane Victorino]], [[Philadelphia Phillies]] | [[Citizens Bank Park]] | [[CC Sabathia]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]] | align="center" | 2nd | align="center" | 5–1 | align="center" | 5–2, W | align="center" | 2–0 PHI | Victorino's slam, the first in Phillies postseason history, broke a 1–1 tie after pitcher [[Brett Myers]] drew a two-out walk in a nine-pitch at-bat. |- | [[2011 American League Division Series|2011 ALDS]] | Game 1, October 1 | [[Robinson Canó]], [[New York Yankees]] | [[Yankee Stadium]] | [[Al Alburquerque]], [[Detroit Tigers]] | align="center" | 6th | align="center" | 8–1 | align="center" | 9–3, W | align="center" | 1–0 NYY | [[Brett Gardner|Gardner]] singled, [[Derek Jeter|Jeter]] stole second, [[Curtis Granderson|Granderson]] walked. After a pitching change, Robinson Canó hit a 375-foot blast to give the Yankees an 8–1 lead over the Tigers. Cano hit six RBIs this game, barely missing another homer in the previous inning. He tied the Yankees post-season single game record. This was the first home run hit off of Alburquerque this season. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2011 National League Division Series|2011 NLDS]] | Game 3, October 4 | [[Paul Goldschmidt]], [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] | [[Chase Field]] | [[Shaun Marcum]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]] | align="center" | 5th | align="center" | 7–1 | align="center" | 8–1, W | align="center" | 2–1 MIL | Back-to-back singles to [[Josh Collmenter]] and [[Willie Bloomquist]]. Two outs later, with first base open, Marcum intentionally walked [[Miguel Montero]], who had two RBIs to that point in the game, to get to Goldschmidt. Marcum jumped ahead of Goldschmidt, 1–2, before leaving a fastball out over the plate. Goldschmidt drove the ball the opposite way and over the wall in right to give Arizona a 7–1 lead. Goldschmidt became the third rookie to hit a postseason grand slam. |- | [[2011 National League Division Series|2011 NLDS]] | Game 4, October 5 | [[Ryan Roberts]], [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] | [[Chase Field]] | [[Randy Wolf]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]] | align="center" | 1st | align="center" | 4–1 | align="center" | 10–6, W | align="center" | 2–2 | Bloomquist singled out in centerfield. [[Aaron Hill (baseball)|Aaron Hill]] fouled out to first base. [[Justin Upton]] walked, while Montero singled out in the right field. Goldschmidt, who hit a grand slam a day earlier, struck out looking. Wolf jumped behind of Roberts, 2–1, before leaving a 79 mph changeup out over the plate. Roberts drove the ball to opposite and over the wall in left to give Arizona a 4–1 lead. Moments later, [[Chris Young (outfielder)|Chris Young]] hit a home run out to centerfield. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2011 American League Championship Series|2011 ALCS]] | Game 2, October 10 | [[Nelson Cruz]], [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] | [[Rangers Ballpark in Arlington]] | [[Ryan Perry]], [[Detroit Tigers]] | align="center" | 11th | align="center" | 7–3 | align="center" | 7–3, W | align="center" | 2–0 TEX | In the 11th, after Perry came in to replace Valverde, Michael Young singles on a sharp ground ball to left fielder Ryan Raburn. Adrián Beltré singles on a line drive to center fielder Austin Jackson. Michael Young to 2nd. Coaching visit to mound. Mike Napoli singles on a fly ball to center fielder Austin Jackson, loading the bases. Nelson Cruz hits a grand slam (3) to left field. Young, Beltre, and Napoli score on the home run. First official (see [[Grand Slam Single]]) walk-off grand slam in post season history. "<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2011_10_10_slnmlb_milmlb_1&mode=gameday&partnerId=LR_gameday#gid=2011_10_10_detmlb_texmlb_1&mode=recap&c_id=tex Full Nelson: Cruz belts walk-off slam in 11th]" by T.R. Sullivan, MLB.com. Accessed Oct 10, 2011.</ref> |- | [[2012 National League Division Series|2012 NLDS]] | Game 5, October 11 | [[Buster Posey]], [[San Francisco Giants]] | [[Great American Ball Park]] | [[Mat Latos]], [[Cincinnati Reds]] | align="center" | 5th | align="center" | 6–0 | align="center" | 6–4, W | align="center" | 3–2 SF | After the Giants scored two runs in the inning, the bases were loaded for Posey. He hit a home run off the upper deck, giving the Giants a 6–0 lead they did not relinquish. The runs proved to be critical, as the Reds rallied to make the game close, but the Giants held on to win 6–4. The win completed the Giants' comeback from being down 2 games to 0 in the series, the first time that happened in NL Divisional play. The Giants won all three on the road, as the series became the second five-game series to not have a single win by a home team (after the [[2010 ALDS]] between the Rangers and Rays). |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2013 American League Championship Series|2013 ALCS]] | Game 2, October 13 | [[David Ortiz]], [[Boston Red Sox]] | [[Fenway Park]] | [[Joaquín Benoit]], [[Detroit Tigers]] | align="center" | 8th | align="center" | 5–5 | align="center" | 6–5, W | align="center" | 1–1 | With the Red Sox trailing 5–1 in the bottom of the eighth, David Ortiz came up with the bases loaded and two out. Ortiz lined Benoit's first pitch into the right field bullpen sending outfielder [[Torii Hunter]] flying over the wall, tying the game at 5. The Red Sox would go on to win the game 6–5 in the bottom of the ninth on a walk off single by [[Jarrod Saltalamacchia]]. |- | [[2013 American League Championship Series|2013 ALCS]] | Game 6, October 19 | [[Shane Victorino]], [[Boston Red Sox]] | [[Fenway Park]] | [[José Veras]], [[Detroit Tigers]] | align="center" | 7th | align="center" | 5–2 | align="center" | 5–2, W | align="center" | 4–2 BOS | In the bottom of the seventh inning, with the Tigers ahead 2–1 and Victorino down in the count 0–2 on well placed curve balls, he sent the third pitch (also a curve ball, but up in the zone) over the [[Green Monster]]. Victorino ended a 2 for 23 slump with this blast becoming only the second player ever, alongside [[Jim Thome]], to have hit two post-season grand slams. |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2014 National League Wild Card Game|2014 NLWCG]] | n/a October 1 | [[Brandon Crawford]], [[San Francisco Giants]] | [[PNC Park]] | [[Edinson Vólquez]], [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] | align="center" | 4th | align="center" | 4–0 | align="center" | 8–0, W | align="center" | n/a | After singles by [[Pablo Sandoval]] and [[Hunter Pence]] and a walk to [[Brandon Belt]], Crawford unloaded the bases with a 362-foot grand slam to right field, opening the game's scoring. His grand slam was the first to be hit by a shortstop in postseason history. |- | [[2016 National League Championship Series|2016 NLCS]] | Game 1, October 15 | [[Miguel Montero]], [[Chicago Cubs]] | [[Wrigley Field]] | [[Joe Blanton]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | align="center" | 8th | align="center" | 7–3 | align="center" | 8–4, W | align="center" | 1–0 CHC | After the Dodgers tied it in the top of the 8th inning, Montero's pinch hit grand slam into the right field bleachers broke the tie. |- |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2017 American League Division Series|2017 ALDS]] | Game 2, October 6 | [[Francisco Lindor]], [[Cleveland Indians]] | [[Progressive Field]] | [[Chad Green (pitcher)|Chad Green]], [[New York Yankees]] | align="center" | 6th | align="center" | 7–8 | align="center" | 9–8, W | align="center" | 2–0 CLE | With two outs in the 6th, [[Lonnie Chisenhall]] was grazed by a 2-strike pitch that appeared to have possibly struck the knob of his bat before landing in the catcher's mitt for an inning-ending foul-tip strikeout. The Yankees chose not to challenge the umpire's call that Chisenhall was hit by the pitch to load the bases. Lindor then blasted a towering fly ball high off the right field foul pole to cut the Yankees' 5-run lead down to 1. The Indians later finished their comeback with a walk-off single by [[Yan Gomes]] in the 13th inning. |- | [[2017 National League Division Series|2017 NLDS]] | Game 4, October 11 | [[Michael Taylor (baseball, born 1991)|Michael A. Taylor]], [[Washington Nationals]] | [[Wrigley Field]] | [[Wade Davis (baseball)|Wade Davis]], [[Chicago Cubs]] | align="center" | 8th | align="center" | 5–0 | align="center" | 5–0, W | align="center" | 2–2 | After inheriting [[Daniel Murphy (baseball)|Daniel Murphy]] on first base from [[Jon Lester]], [[Carl Edwards Jr.]] issued back-to-back 2-out walks to [[Anthony Rendon]] and [[Matt Wieters]] to load the bases. Davis was then brought in to face Taylor with the hope of holding the Nationals' lead at 1–0. Taylor hit a 1–1 fastball from Davis into the chain link net at the top of the right center field wall to clear the bases and expand the lead to 5–0. |- |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2017 National League Championship Series|2017 NLCS]] | Game 5, October 19 | [[Enrique Hernández (baseball)|Kiké Hernández]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | [[Wrigley Field]] | [[Hector Rondon]], [[Chicago Cubs]] | align="center" | 3rd | align="center" | 7–0 | align="center" | 11–1, W | align="center" | 4–1 LAD | Hernández's grand slam on a fly ball to right field was the second of his three home runs on the night, which made Hernández the 10th player ever to hit 3 homers in a postseason game. In this close-out game, Hernández drove in 7 runs to tie the Major League record for RBI in a postseason game and help send the Dodgers to the World Series for the first time since 1988. |- | [[2018 National League Division Series|2018 NLDS]] | Game 3, October 7 | [[Ronald Acuña Jr.]], [[Atlanta Braves]] | [[SunTrust Park]] | [[Walker Buehler]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | align="center" | 2nd | align="center" | 5–0 | align="center" | 6–5, W | align="center" | 2–1 LAD | After pitcher [[Sean Newcomb]] drew a bases-loaded walk to drive in the Braves' first run of the series, breaking a string of 19 2/3 consecutive scoreless innings, Acuña's towering fly ball into the left field bleachers off a 3-1 fastball at the top of the strike zone expanded the Braves' lead to 5-0. (Acuña almost walked in the at-bat after taking a 3-0 fastball that was called a strike despite sailing above the strike zone.) At 20 years and 293 days old, Acuña became the youngest player to hit a postseason grand slam in Major League history, surpassing Mickey Mantle (who was 21 years, 349 days old when he hit one in the 1953 World Series).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/2018/10/07/ronald-acuna-braves-grand-slam-mlb-playoffs/1562252002/|title=Ronald Acuna becomes youngest player with postseason grand slam|work=USA Today|first=Jesse|last=Yomtov|date=October 7, 2018|accessdate=October 7, 2018}}</ref> |- |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" | [[2018 American League Championship Series|2018 ALCS]] | Game 3, October 16 | [[Jackie Bradley Jr.]], [[Boston Red Sox]] | [[Minute Maid Park]] | [[Roberto Osuna]], [[Houston Astros]] | align="center" | 8th | align="center" | 8–2 | align="center" | 8-2, W | align="center" | 2-1 BOS | After consecutive batters [[Brock Holt]] and [[Mitch Moreland]] were hit by pitches to load the bases then drive in a run with two outs, JBJ launched a fly ball over the right field wall to clear the bases and break the game open. |}
==All-star game== {| border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="3" |- style="background-color: #e0e0e0;" ! Year ! Batter ! Date and Site ! Pitcher ! Inning ! Score after HR ! Final score ! Notes |- | {{Baseball year|1983}} | [[Fred Lynn]], [[American League|AL]] ([[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California]]) | July 6, [[Comiskey Park]] | [[Atlee Hammaker]], [[National League|NL]] ([[San Francisco Giants|San Francisco]]) | align="center" | 3rd | align="center" | 9–1 | align="center" | 13–3, W | In the 50th anniversary game, Lynn hits the first grand slam in All-Star history to right field on a 2–2 pitch with two out, capping a 7-run inning and virtually ensuring the AL's first victory since 1971 and second since 1962. Just before the pitch, NBC put on-screen a graphic indicating that there had never been a grand slam hit in All-Star history. |}
==Career grand slam leaders== {|align=right |[[File:Alex Rodriguez 2008-04-19.jpg|thumb|right|140px|Alex Rodriguez currently holds the record for most career grand slams with 25.]] |[[File:GehrigCU.jpg|thumb|right|180px|With 23 grand slams, Lou Gehrig held the all-time record until 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lou Gehrig Grand Slams|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/Lou_Gehrig_Grand_Slams.shtml|work=Baseball Almanac|accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref>]] |} {| |- |* [[Alex Rodriguez]]     || 25 |- |* [[Lou Gehrig]] || 23 |- |* [[Manny Ramírez]] || 21 |- |* [[Eddie Murray]] || 19 |- |* [[Willie McCovey]] || 18 <small>[1]</small> |- |* [[Robin Ventura]] || 18 |- |* [[Carlos Lee]] || 17 |- |* [[Jimmie Foxx]] || 17 |- |* [[Ted Williams]] || 17 |- |* [[Hank Aaron]] || 16 |- |* [[Dave Kingman]] || 16 |- |* [[Babe Ruth]] || 16 |- |*[[Ryan Howard]] || 15 |- |* [[Ken Griffey, Jr.]] || 15 |- |* [[Richie Sexson]] || 15 |- |* [[Jason Giambi]] || 14 |- |* [[Gil Hodges]] || 14 |- |* [[Mark McGwire]] || 14 |- |* [[Mike Piazza]] || 14 |}  <small>1 – National League record</small>

'''Hipódromo Camarero''', formerly known as '''El Nuevo Comandante''', is a [[horse racing]] building located in [[Canóvanas, Puerto Rico]], to the east of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] and [[Carolina, Puerto Rico|Carolina]]. It is about a fifteen-minute drive from Carolina's [[Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport]], and 25 minutes east from the Isla Verde [[hotel]] area. The new administration of Camarero Race Track Corporation start operations on January 5, 2007.
El Nuevo Comandante was built in 1976,and opened on October 31, 1976, to substitute the original "El Comandante" building, which had been located in Carolina, from January 1957 to mid October 1976. It has become arguably the most important horse racing complex in the island, holding horse races every Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
El Nuevo Comandante features a [[gambling|betting]] window, in which players can try their luck at different games, such as "El Pool Pote" and others. The top award a player can win at El Nuevo Comandante is the "Pool Pote" (Pool Pot) and it reached a staggering 12 Million dollars and has been the largest pot ever won in Puerto Rico's Horse Racing Industry. In addition to the betting windows at El Nuevo Comandante, the Industry has a link of betting agencies throughout Puerto Rico. These are called "agencias hipicas", and people can go there to place bets as well and enjoy local refreshments and snacks.
Races at "El Nuevo Comandante" have been shown on local [[television]] and Les Oraliens on [[radio]] since the building was inaugurated. Some of the most famous television sportscasters in [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] history have commented from there, including [[Norman H. Davila]] and [[Manolo Rivera Morales]].
Some famous jockeys have run there too, including Hall of Famer [[Angel Cordero]], John Velazquez and [[J.C. Diaz]].
Famous horses imported to run at El Nuevo Comandante have been: Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes winner [[Bold Forbes]], Santa Anita Derby winner [[Mister Frisk]]y, Bandit Bomber and [[Dawn Glory]] (Stakes winner in USA).
Among the native horses: Hurly Road (Triple Crown winner), Ribot's Verset (one of the best sires in Puerto Rican history), My favorite Place (Multiple allowance winner in California) Capa Prieto (undefeated for years), [[Camarero]] (Holds a record of 56 consecutive wins in a row), Vuelve Candy B (Triple Crown and Caribbean Derby winner and the only horse to earn a million dollars in Puerto Rico), Verset Dancer (Caribbean Derby winner and winner in USA) and Verset's Jet (son of Verset Dancer) who's the first horse to complete the Caribbean Derby and Confraternidad Stakes double.
El Nuevo Comandante also has the infamous distinction (Guinness record) of having the horse with the most consecutive losses (Dona Chepa) with 134 consecutive loses (through 11/2/08 without a win){{citation needed|date=July 2016}}
El Nuevo Comandante is also the site where the most famous race in the [[Caribbean]] has been held for 32 years: The [[Clasico del Caribe]] is celebrated there yearly, with horses participating from Colombia, Venezuela, Dominican Republic, Mexico, Panama, Trinidad and Tobago, Jamaica and Puerto Rico, among other countries.
==External links== *[http://hipodromo-camarero.com Official website] *[http://ramonrodriguez.nstemp.com/ (El Nuevo Comandante information is available here in Spanish)]

{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Jinnah Stadium, Gujranwala | nickname = Municipal Stadium | country = Pakistan | location = [[Gujranwala]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] | coordinates = {{Coord|32|9|49|N|74|11|27|E|type:landmark|display=t}} | image = | seating_capacity = 40000 | owner = [[Pakistan Cricket]] | Curator = Alhaj Muhammad Aslam Butt | tenants = [[Pakistan national cricket team]]
Gujranwala Cricket Association | end1 = | end2 = | international = yes | onlytestdate = 20 December | onlytestyear = 1991 | onlytesthome = Pakistan | onlytestaway = Sri Lanka | firstodidate = 3 December | firstodiyear = 1982 | firstodihome = Pakistan | firstodiaway = India | lastodidate = 16 February | lastodiyear = 2000 | lastodihome = Pakistan | lastodiaway = Sri Lanka | firstt20idate = | firstt20iyear = | firstt20ihome = | firstt20iaway = | lastt20idate = | lastt20iyear = | lastt20ihome = | lastt20iaway = | year1 = | club1 = | year2 = | club2 = | date = 29 December | year = 2016 | source = ESPNcricinfo{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/58930.html|title=Jinnah Stadium - Pakistan - Cricket Grounds - ESPN Cricinfo|author=|date=|work=ESPNCricinfo.com|access-date=26 April 2017}} }} '''Jinnah Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Gujranwala]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]]. It is used mostly for [[cricket]] matches. The stadium capacity is 40000 {{Cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1319194 |title=Stadium stories: Famous Pakistan cricket grounds |access-date=11 March 2017 |work=Dawn}} and it hosted its first and only Test match in 1991.{{cite web |title=Jinnah Stadium |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/58930.html |work=ESPN Cricinfo |date=17 June 2011 |access-date=17 June 2011 }} [[List of One Day International cricket records#Individual records (batting)|Record-breaking]] Indian batsman [[Sachin Tendulkar]] made his [[One-day international|ODI cricket]] debut in 1989 at this ground.{{cite web|title= Sachin Tendulkar|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/player/35320.html?class=2;template=results;type=allround;view=match|work= ESPN Cricinfo}} The last ODI match played there was between [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] in 2000 and was the first ODI match [[Aleem Dar]] umpired.{{cite web |title=Aleem Dar |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/player/39157.html?class=2;player_type=2;template=results;type=official;view=match|work=ESPN Cricinfo}} The creator of this stadium is Alhaj Muhammad Aslam Butt (former mayor of Gujranwala). The stadium was designed by Amjad Saleem Tahir CEO Of Aeys Associates and is located on Sialkot road. Today,{{When|date=April 2017}} it is mostly used for [[sports day]] of [[schools]]. ==Cricket World Cup== This stadium hosted an ODI match in the 1996 Cricket World Cup between [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] and [[United Arab Emirates national cricket team|UAE]].{{cite web|title=ODI Match List|url=http://www.howstat.com.au/cricket/Statistics/Matches/MatchList_ODI.asp?Group=1996010119961231&Range=1996|work=HowStat!}} ==One Day International centuries== The following table summarises the One Day International centuries scored at Jinnah Stadium, Gujranwala. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" ! No. !! Score !! Player !! Team !! Balls !! Inns. !! Opposing team !! Date !! {{Infobox film | name = Me & Bobby Fischer | image = | caption = | producer = [[Fridrik Gudmundsson (producer)|Fridrik Gudmundsson]] | writer = Fridrik Gudmundsson | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Bobby Fischer]] * [[Saemundur Palsson]]}} | music = {{Plainlist| * [[Einar Arnaldur Melax]] * [[Guðlaugur Kristinn Óttarsson]] * [[Óttar Proppe]] * [[Björk|Björk Guðmundsdóttir]] * [[Jón Ísólfsson]]}} | cinematography = Fridrik Gudmundsson | editing = | distributor = Fridrik Gudmundsson | released = {{Film date|2009|4|17}} | runtime = 82 minutes | country = Iceland | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Me & Bobby Fischer''''' is a documentary about [[Bobby Fischer]]'s last years as his old friend Saemundur Palsson gets him out of jail in [[Japan]] and helps him settle in [[Iceland]].
The film premiered at the Green Light Films’ [[Bíódagar film festival]] in April 2009.<ref>[http://www.ficgs.com/Me-Bobby-Fischer-f3580.html Free Internet Chess - FICGS website]. Accessed February 20, 2010.</ref><ref>Catharine Fulto, "Iceland’s ties to Recluse Anti-Semitic Chess Grandmaster: New Bobby Fischer doc examines an unlikely friendship." ''Reykjavik Grapevine''. August 5, 2009. Found at [http://www.grapevine.is/Art/ReadArticle/Film-Me-and-Bobby-Fischer ''Reykjavik Grapevine'' website]. Accessed February 20, 2010.</ref>
==Cast== * [[Bobby Fischer]] * [[Saemundur Palsson]] * [[Kári Stefánsson]]
==Festivals== * [[Green Light Reykjavik]]
==See also== * [[List of books and documentaries by or about Bobby Fischer]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{infobox country at games | NPC = NCA | NPCname = Comité Paralímpico Nicaragüense | games = Paralympics | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = {{Team appearances list|team=Nicaragua|competition=Summer Paralympics|begin_year=|end_year= }} | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Nicaragua]]''' made its [[Paralympic Games]] début at the [[2004 Summer Paralympics]] in [[Athens]]. Its sole representative, wheelchair athlete [[Mario Madriz]], entered two events in athletics. Nicaragua did not take part in the [[2008 Summer Paralympics|2008 Summer Games]], and has never participated in the [[Winter Paralympics]].[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=NCA&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Nicaragua at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] ==Full results for Nicaragua at the Paralympics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Games !Sport !Event !Score !Rank |- | [[Mario Madriz]] || [[2004 Summer Paralympics|2004 Athens]] || [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's 100 m T54 || 19.74 || 8th (last) in heat 4;
did not advance |- | Mario Madriz || 2004 Athens || Athletics || Men's 5,000 m T54 || dnf || dnf in heat 2;
did not advance |} ==See also== * [[Nicaragua at the Olympics]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Nations at the Paralympics}} [[Category:Nicaragua at the Paralympics| ]] {{Nicaragua-sport-stub}} {{Paralympics-stub}}
