The first women international match is played: [[France women's national football team|France]] 4 [[Netherlands women's national football team|Netherlands]] 0. *'''[[1972 in association football|1972 in football]]''' [[Tottenham Hotspur]] wins the first [[UEFA Cup]]. [[AFC Ajax]] wins the first edition of the [[UEFA Super Cup]]. *'''[[1973 in association football|1973 in football]]''' [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] win the European Cup for the third consecutive season. The first [[OFC Nations Cup]] is organized and won by New Zealand. *'''[[1974 in association football|1974 in football]]''' Hosts [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] win the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]], beating the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] 2–1 in the final. *'''[[1975 in association football|1975 in football]]''' The [[AFC Women's Asian Cup]] is organized for the first time in Hong Kong, won by [[New Zealand women's national football team|New Zealand]]. *'''[[1976 in association football|1976 in football]]''' [[Bayern Munich]] win the European Cup for the third consecutive season. [[Iran national football team|Iran national team]] win its third consecutive [[Asian Cup]], a record. *'''[[1977 in association football|1977 in football]]''' Juventus become the first Italian and South European club to win the [[UEFA Cup]]. The first [[FIFA U-20 World Cup]] is organized in Tunisia, and won by USSR. *'''[[1978 in association football|1978 in football]]''' Hosts [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] win the [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978 World Cup]], beating the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] 3–1 in the final; [[Johann Cruyff]] refuses to play in the tournament. *'''[[1979 in association football|1979 in football]]''' [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] lift their first [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] in [[Munich]], defeating [[Malmö FF|Malmö]] 1–0 in the final.
== 1980s == *'''[[1980 in association football|1980 in football]]''' [[German national football team|West Germany]] defeats [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] 2–1 in the final at the [[Stadio Olimpico]] in [[Rome]] to take the [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Football Championship]]. *'''[[1981 in association football|1981 in football]]''' [[The Football League]] begins awarding three points for a win instead of two. In Uruguay, to celebrate the 50 years of the World Cup, the [[1980 Mundialito]] is organized, won by the hosts. *'''[[1982 in association football|1982 in football]]''' **The [[1982 FIFA World Cup]] is played in [[Spain]], the first with 24 teams, the tournament was won by [[Italy national football team|Italy]], after defeating [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] 3–1 in the final in the Spanish capital of Madrid. It was Italy's third World Cup win and first since [[1938 FIFA World Cup|1938]]. The holders [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] were eliminated in the second group round. Algeria, Cameroon, Honduras, Kuwait and New Zealand made their first appearances in the finals. for the first time all continents were represented in the competition. **[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] win the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]], beating [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] 1–0 in the final. *'''[[1983 in association football|1983 in football]]''' [[Aberdeen FC|Aberdeen]] beat [[Real Madrid]] to win their first European Trophy, the European Cup Winners' Cup soon followed by defeating [[Hamburger SV|Hamburg]] to win the European Super Cup. The [[OFC Women's Championship]] is played for the first time in New Caledonia, won by New Zealand. *'''[[1984 in association football|1984 in football]]''' [[Michel Platini]] leads Juventus to the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]], beating [[F.C. Porto]] in the final and the hosts [[France national football team|France]] to the [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Football Championship]], beating [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in the final. France also wins the [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics|gold medal in the 1984 Olympic Games]], beating [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in the final at the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]]. The [[UEFA Women's Championship]] is organized for the first time, won by [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden]]. *'''[[1985 in association football|1985 in football]]''' The [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] takes place in [[Brussels]] at the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] final between [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], leading to English clubs being banned from European club competition for five years. Juventus becomes the [[UEFA competition records#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|first club in the history of European football]] to have won all three major [[UEFA competition records|UEFA competitions]] after defeating Liverpool 1–0 in the [[European Cup 1984-85#Final|European Cup final]], and thus far, the only in association football history, to have won all possible [[:Category:UEFA club competitions|confederation competitions]]<ref name="official">In addition, Juventus F.C. were the first club in association football history to have won all possible confederation competitions (e.g. the international tournaments [[List of UEFA club competition winners|organised by UEFA]]) and remain the only in the world to achieve this, cf. {{Cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/supercup/news/kind=32/newsid=447085.html |title=Legend: UEFA club competitions |publisher=Union des Associations Européennes de Football |date=21 August 2006 |accessdate=26 February 2013 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131103346/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/supercup/news/kind=32/newsid=447085.html |archivedate=January 31, 2010 }}<br />{{Cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/eusa/history/season=1985/intro.html |title=1985: Juventus end European drought |publisher=Union des Associations Européennes de Football |date=8 December 1985 |accessdate=26 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208125358/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/eusa/history/season=1985/intro.html |archivedate=December 8, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=April 2004 – May 2005|title=FIFA Club World Championship TOYOTA Cup: Solidarity – the name of the game|journal=FIFA Activity Report 2005|page=62|location=[[Zurich]]|publisher=Fédération Internationale de Football Association|format=PDF|accessdate=17 December 2012|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/01/68/21/16//activityreport2005en.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=107/edition=4735/news/newsid=101662.html|title=We are the champions|publisher=Fédération Internationale de Football Association|date=2005-12-01|accessdate=2009-10-28}}</ref> after defeating [[Argentinos Juniors]] 6–4 (2–2 [[Extra time|a.e.t]].) in the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] final at Tokyo's [[National Stadium Tokyo|National Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/index.html#club=31085 | title=FIFA Classic Clubs: Juventus FC | work=fifa.com | accessdate=15 December 2006}}.</ref> The [[Bradford City stadium fire]] occurs at [[Valley Parade]], taking the lives of 56 people and injuring another 200 during [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]]'s fixture with [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]]. For the first time, an African squad wins a FIFA tournament, the [[FIFA U-16 World Championship 1985|World Championship Under 16]], as Nigeria surprisingly defeat favourites West Germany 2–0 in China. The [[Artemio Franchi Trophy]] is organized for the first time, won and hosted by France. [[Michel Platini]] wins for the third consecutive time the [[Ballon d'Or]], a record then. *'''[[1986 in association football|1986 in football]]''' The [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986 World Cup]] finals are played for the second time in Mexico, with [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] defeating [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] 3–2 for their second title at the [[Azteca Stadium]] in Mexico City; the tournament sees the dominance of Argentinian player [[Diego Maradona]], scoring the infamous [[Hand of God goal]], before his "[[Goal of the Century]]" solo dribble second goal, both in the quarterfinal against [[England national football team|England]]. [[Alex Ferguson]], the most decorated manager in [[English Football]] history, is appointed to be manager of Manchester United. *'''[[1987 in association football|1987 in football]]''' [[Futebol Clube do Porto|F.C. Porto]] wins the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] for the first time after defeating [[Bayern Munich]] 2–1 in the final. In the second [[FIFA U-16 World Championship 1987|World Championship FIFA Under 16]], the [[USSR national football team|Soviet Union]] defeats [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] on penalties. The [[OFC Champions League]] is played for the first time and won by [[Adelaide City]]. *'''[[1988 in association football|1988 in football]]''' The [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]], led by captain [[Ruud Gullit]] and top goal scorer [[Marco van Basten]], defeat the [[USSR national football team|Soviet Union]] 2–0 to win the [[1988 European Football Championship|Euro 1988]] championship. Competing in [[Serie B]], [[Atalanta B.C|Atalanta]] reaches the Cup Winners' Cup semifinal, the best ever performance by a non-first division club in a major UEFA competition to this day. Start of the FIFA Fair Play campaign. *'''[[1989 in association football|1989 in football]]''' The [[Hillsborough disaster]] occurs in [[Sheffield]], England, before the [[FA Cup]] semi-final between [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], resulting in the loss of 96 lives. A football tournament is played for the first time at the [[Island Games]], by FAs not admitted to FIFA, hosted and won by [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]]. Saudi Arabia win the [[FIFA U-17 World Cup]], the first time an Asian team wins a FIFA World Cup.
== 1990s == *'''[[1990 in association football|1990 in football]]''' For the first time three clubs from the same country, Italy's Juventus, Sampdoria and A.C. Milan wins all four UEFA club competitions in the same season, a feat no more possible since the Cup Winner's Cup no longer exists. [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] wins the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] in Rome, Italy, defeating defending champion [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] 1–0 in the final. In their first appearance in the tournament, [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] reaches the quarter-finals without winning a single game, the furthest a team has ever advanced without winning. "[[Waterloo Day]]" for Austrian football in [[1992 European Football Championship (qualifying)|Euro 92 qualifying]] at [[Landskrona]], Sweden, where the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]] defeat [[Austria national football team|Austria]] 1–0 in the former's first ever international match. *'''[[1991 in association football|1991 in football]]''' In the inaugural [[FIFA Women's World Cup|Women's World Cup]] held in China, the USA win 2–1 over Norway (for the first time a Northern American team win a World Cup). After being banned for six years, English clubs are again allowed to participate in competitions sponsored by [[UEFA]]. [[Diego Maradona]] is banned for 15 months in Italy's [[Serie A]] after testing positive for [[cocaine]] in a [[drug test]]. The [[CAF Women's Championship]] is played for the first time won by Nigeria. The [[CONCACAF Women's Gold Cup]] is played for the first time in Haiti, won by USA. The [[Sudamericano Femenino]], CONMEBOL's main women's tournament, is played for the first time, hosted and won by Brazil. The [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] is assigned for the first time. *'''[[1992 in association football|1992 in football]]''' The back-pass rule is applied, whereby a goalkeeper is no longer permitted to pick up or catch a ball played directly by a fellow team member's foot. In the final of [[1992 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 92]], [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] surprisingly win 2–0 over Germany. [[Stade Armand Cesari|Stadium Furiani]] disaster takes place in [[Bastia]], [[Corsica]]. [[FA Premier League]] created as the top flight in English Football. The first [[FIFA Confederations Cup]] is organized in Saudi Arabia, and won by Argentina. [[Fabio Capello|Capello]]'s Milan wins Serie A unbeaten. *'''[[1993 in association football|1993 in football]]''' [[Olympique de Marseille]] becomes the first French club to win the European Cup, newly renamed as the [[UEFA Champions League]], defeating [[AC Milan]] 1–0 at the [[Olympiastadion (Munich)|Olympiastadion]] in Munich. Marseille also win [[Ligue 1]], but are stripped of the title due to a corruption scandal. 18 members of the [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]] national team [[Gabon air disaster|die in a plane crash]]. Manchester United win the first [[FA Premier League]] title. [[Brian Clough]] retires from his coaching role in [[Nottingham Forest]] after 18 years as coach. *'''[[1994 in association football|1994 in football]]''' The [[1994 World Cup]] held in the United States was the first to be decided on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalties]], with Brazil edging out [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the final at the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] to claim their fourth title. [[Russia national football team|Russia]]'s Oleg Salenko becomes the first player and only to this day to score five goals in a single World Cup game in his country's 6–1 win over [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]]. In the same match, 42-year-old [[Roger Milla]] of Cameroon, becomes the oldest player ever to score in a World Cup match. *'''[[1995 in association football|1995 in football]]''' The second [[1995 King Fahd Cup|FIFA Confederations Cup]] is organized in Saudi Arabia, and won by Denmark. The [[Bosman ruling]] allows all footballers playing in the [[European Union]] and not under contract to freely change clubs, and also abolishes foreign player quotas with respect to EU nationals. {{wnft|Norway}} win the second [[FIFA Women's World Cup]]. [[Suwon Samsung Bluewings]] is founded. *'''[[1996 in association football|1996 in football]]''' [[Bayern Munich]] becomes the third club in the history of European football to have won all three major UEFA competitions after winning the [[UEFA Cup]]. In the [[1996 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 96]] final, [[Germany national football team|Germany]] defeat the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] 2–1 with a [[golden goal]] from [[Oliver Bierhoff]]; [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] become the first [[Confederation of African Football|African]] team to win the [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|Olympic Tournament]]. A football women's tournament is played for the first time at the [[Summer Olympics]] in Atlanta, won by the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]]. *'''[[1997 in association football|1997 in football]]''' [[Helenio Herrera]], legendary trainer of [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Inter]] in the 1960s, dies. *'''[[1998 in association football|1998 in football]]''' In the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] final, [[France national football team|France]] win 3–0 over [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] at [[Stade de France]] to claim their first World Cup. [[Palestinian Football Federation]] is admitted to FIFA. The first openly gay footballer, [[Justin Fashanu]] commits suicide. *'''[[1999 in association football|1999 in football]]''' The [[United States women's national soccer team|USA]], the hosting nation, defeat [[China women's national football team|China]] in a [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty shootout]] to win the [[FIFA Women's World Cup 1999|Women's World Cup]] in front of the largest crowd ever to witness a women's sporting event. Organized in Italy by [[UEFA]] the first continental tournament for regions: the [[UEFA Regions' Cup]], won by [[Veneto]]. Mexico win the [[1999 FIFA Confederations Cup|Confederations Cup]]: for the first time a male national team form Northern America win a FIFA tournament. The UEFA Cup Winners' Cup is abolished.
== 2000s == *'''[[2000 in association football|2000 in football]]''' [[France national football team|France]] wins their second [[2000 European Football Championship|European Championship]] title after beating [[Italy national football team|Italy]] 2–1, with a [[golden goal]] in extra time. First [[FIFA Club World Cup]], won by [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista]]. [[FIFA Player of the Century]], a one-off award created by FIFA to decide the greatest football player of the 20th century, is awarded to [[Pele|Pelé]] and [[Diego Maradona]], shared: both men are officially considered winners of the award. *'''[[2001 in association football|2001 in football]]''' [[Real Madrid]] sign playmaker [[Zinedine Zidane]] of [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] in a world record transfer fee of 72 million euros. Colombia wins the 40th edition of [[2001 Copa América|Copa América]], [[Colombia|as]] hosts. [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]] beats [[American Samoa national football team|American Samoa]] [[Australia 31–0 American Samoa|31–0]] in 2002 World Cup qualification, the world record in an international match. *'''[[2002 in association football|2002 in football]]''' [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] sets up a record fifth title in [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] competition, the first ever to be played in Asia (also the first outside Europe and the Americas), defeating [[Germany national football team|Germany]] 2–0 in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]] final. The first [[FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship|FIFA U-19 Women's World Championship]] is held in Canada, with the [[United States women's national soccer team|USA]] defeating [[Canada women's national soccer team|the hosts]] in the final 1–0 on a [[golden goal]] in extra time. *'''[[2003 in association football|2003 in football]]''' Founded the [[NF-Board]], the first international organization for FAs not admitted to FIFA. [[Paolo Maldini]] makes history by captaining AC Milan to a [[2002–03 UEFA Champions League|champions league]] victory, a feat his father [[Cesare Maldini|Cesare]] did with the same club exactly 40 years before. [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] is the first football team from the [[Baltic states]] to make an appearance in a major football competition, [[UEFA Euro 2004]]. *'''[[2004 in association football|2004 in football]]''' [[Greece national football team|Greece]] produce one of the shocks in football history and become surprise winners of the [[2004 European Football Championship|Euro 2004]] football tournament, defeating hosts [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] 1–0 in the final. [[Waitakere United]] is founded. [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] wins the [[2003-04 FA Premier League]] [[The Invincibles (football)|unbeaten]], the second time an English club goes undefeated for an entire season. *'''[[2005 in association football|2005 in football]]''' The [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|Champions League final]] in [[Istanbul]] sees [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] come back from a 0–3 half-time score to defeat [[A.C. Milan]] 3–2 in a [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty shootout]], following a 3–3 draw. Also, [[2005 Bundesliga scandal|a match-fixing scandal]] rocks German football, though it does not directly affect the [[Bundesliga]]. The Australian [[A-League]] is launched in replacement of the NSL to improve the quality of the game in the country. *'''[[2006 in association football|2006 in football]]''' The [[2006 World Cup]] is held in Germany and won by Italy on a penalty kick shootout over France, and [[Zinedine Zidane]] plays his last professional game in the final captaining France only to be sent off in extra time. A [[2006 Serie A scandal|major match-fixing scandal]] erupts in Italy, with five [[Serie A]] teams implicated. [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] record victory for the fifth time in the [[2006 African Cup of Nations|African Cup of Nations]]. *'''[[2007 in association football|2007 in football]]''' Brazil wins the 42nd edition of [[2007 Copa América|Copa América]], held in [[Venezuela]]. [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] produce one of international football's greatest fairytale victories as the fractured, war-torn nation were crowned champions of the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]]. [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup|FIFA Women's World Cup]] is held in China and won by Germany. On 9 November [[Étoile Sportive du Sahel]] became the first African squad to have won all official club competitions recognized by [[Confédération Africaine de Football|CAF]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/caf-ranking.html | title=African club competitions recognized by CAF | work=rsssf.com | accessdate=23 March 2008}}.</ref> after defeating [[Al-Ahly]] 3–1 in the [[CAF Champions League 2007#Final|CAF Champions League final]] in [[Susa]]. *'''[[2008 in association football|2008 in football]]''' Spain win their second [[UEFA Euro 2008|European Championship]] title after beating Germany 1–0. Italy and [[A.C. Milan]] becomes the first national and club side to wear on their jerseys the FIFA badge of World champions.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/10/italian-football/2008/09/02/846333/blatter-presents-italy-with-historic-world-champions-badge | title= Blatter presents Italy with historic World champions badge | work=fifa.com | accessdate=11 February 2016}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/clubworldcup/news/y=2008/m=2/news=fifa-awards-special-club-world-champion-badge-milan-687173.html | title= FIFA Awards special club World champion badge to AC Milan | work=fifa.com | accessdate=11 February 2016}}.</ref> [[CONCACAF Champions Cup]] is replaced by the [[CONCACAF Champions League]], modelled after the [[UEFA Champions League]] expand his participant teams from 8 to 24. The [[FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]] is played for the first time in New Zealand, won by Korea DPR. The [[Women's Viva World Cup]], the first World Cup for women's national teams not affiliated to FIFA, is played for the first time, hosted and won by Sapmi. *'''[[2009 in association football|2009 in football]]''' The [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup|FIFA Confederations Cup]] is won by Brazil and is held in South Africa (for the first time a FIFA tournament for senior national teams is held in Africa). [[Spain national football team|Spain]] achieves two world records: most consecutive wins (15) and most matches without a loss (35, with Brazil). [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] achieves a sextuple: [[La Liga]], [[Copa del Rey]], [[Supercopa de España]], [[UEFA Champions League]], [[UEFA Super Cup]] and [[FIFA Club World Cup]].
== 2010s == *'''[[2010 in association football|2010 in football]]''' ** The [[2010 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] is held in [[South Africa]], the first African nation to host the tournament. [[Spain national football team|Spain]] win the World Cup for the first time, becoming the first nation outside of South America to win the tournament outside of Europe. ** The [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] is awarded for the first time (to [[Lionel Messi]]) after France Football's [[Ballon d'Or]] and the [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] award were merged. ** [[Egypt]] win the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Cup of Nations]] for the third time in a row. ** [[Inter Milan]] win the [[2010 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for the first time, beating [[TP Mazembe]], the first African club to reach the final. *'''[[2011 in association football|2011 in football]]''' ** Japan defeat the United States in the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|FIFA Women's World Cup]] final to win the tournament for the first time. ** [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] wins the [[2011 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for a then-record second time, beating [[Santos FC|Santos]] in the final. *'''[[2012 in association football|2012 in football]]''' ** [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]] defeats third-time finalists [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] after a dramatic penalty shootout in the final, giving Zambia their first continental title, becoming the fourteenth nation to win the tournament. ** [[Tahiti national football team|Tahiti]] wins the [[2012 OFC Nations Cup|OFC Nations Cup]] for the first time, becoming the first nation other than Australia or New Zealand to win the tournament. ** The [[2012 VIVA World Cup]], played in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], with 9 participants, holds the largest number of participating teams for a non-FIFA tournament. The hosts emerge as winners in the final match played against [[Northern Cyprus]], who fail to win a [[Non-FIFA football|non-FIFA]] tournament in which they took part for the first time. ** Spain wins the 2012 [[European Championship]]: for the first time the trophy was won by the same team twice in a row. **[[Lionel Messi]] scores 91 goals, establishing the new world record for most goals scored in a single [[calendar year]], surpassing [[Gerd Müller]]'s record of 85 set in [[1972 in association football|1972]]. ** [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]] wins the [[2012 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for the second time, beating [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the final. *'''[[2013 in association football|2013 in football]]''' ** [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] wins the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Cup of Nations]] for the third time, ending their 19-year wait after defeating surprise finalists [[Burkina Faso national football team|Burkina Faso]]. ** Nigeria wins the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup|FIFA U-17 World Cup]] for a record fourth time. ** [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] wins the [[2013 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for the first time, beating [[Raja Casablanca]] in the final. *'''[[2014 in association football|2014 in football]]''' ** Japan wins the [[2014 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup|FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]] for the first time. ** The [[2014 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] is held in [[Brazil]] for the second time, the first South American nation to host the tournament in 36 years. ** [[Julio Grondona]], continuous president of AFA since 1979 dies in office. ** The [[2014 FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup|FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup]] is held in [[Canada]], the first nation to host the tournament twice. ** [[Germany]] wins both competitions above. ** German [[Miroslav Klose]] becomes the all time FIFA World Cup top scorer with 16 goals. ** [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] becomes the first team in European history to win 10 European titles and wins the [[2014 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for the first time, beating [[San Lorenzo de Almagro|San Lorenzo]] in the final. *'''[[2015 in association football|2015 in football]]''' ** The [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup|FIFA Women's World Cup]] is held in [[Canada]], United States defeat Japan in the final to win the tournament for the third time. ** Chile win the [[2015 Copa America|Copa America]] for the first time, in home soil after defeat Argentina in the final. ** The [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] is awarded (to [[Lionel Messi]]) and he won the fifth [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] in his career. ** [[Australia]] win the [[2015 AFC Asian Cup|AFC Asian Cup]] for the first time. ** [[Sepp Blatter]] (1998–2015) ends his tenure as president of FIFA and is replaced by the acting president [[Issa Hayatou]]. ** [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] win the [[2015 FIFA Club World Cup|FIFA Club World Cup]] for the third time, beating [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]], in the final. *'''[[2016 in association football|2016 in football]]''' **[[Lionel Messi]] ({{fb|ARG}}, {{flagicon|ESP}}[[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] wins the 2015 FIFA Ballon d'Or and [[Carli Lloyd]] ({{fbw|USA}}, {{flagicon|USA}} [[Houston Dash]]) wins 2015 FIFA Women's World Player of the Year. **[[Gianni Infantino]] is elected president of FIFA. **[[Copa America Centenario]] is hosted in the United States, the first time the Copa is held outside of South America. 16 teams from CONMEBOL and CONCACAF participate, and the tournament is won by [[Chile national football team|Chile]] on penalties after defeating [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in the final. **[[Euro 2016]] is held in France, the third time the nation hosts it. [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] defeats France 1–0 in the final to claim their first major championship in their history. *'''[[2017 in association football|2017 in football]]''' **in January, [[The Best FIFA Football Awards 2016]] [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] ({{fb|POR|Portugal}}, [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]) wins The Best FIFA Men's Player and [[Carli Lloyd]] ([[Houston Dash]], {{fbw|USA|United States}}) The Best FIFA Women's Player. **in May, [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] becomes the first team in [[Football in Italy|Italian football history]] to win 6 [[Serie A|national titles]] in a row and the first in win the [[Coppa Italia|Italian Cup]] thrice consecutively, beating [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] in the final. **In October, [[FIFA Council]] officially recognized all European and South American teams that won the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] as club world champions with the same status to the [[FIFA Club World Cup]] winners.<ref>{{cite press release |date=27 October 2017 |title=FIFA Council approves key organisational elements of the FIFA World Cup |url=https://www.fifa.com/about-fifa/news/y=2017/m=10/news=fifa-council-approves-key-organisational-elements-of-the-fifa-world-cu-2917722.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref>
** Manchester United become the Europa League champions and Real Madrid win Champions League *'''[[2018 in association footbal|2018 in football]] **Liverpool's [[Mohamed Salah]] breaks record for the most goals scored in a 38-game season in the Premier League. Salah also won goal of the year and the PL golden boot.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/liverpool-brighton-premier-league-match-report-mohamed-salah-record-a8349831.html|title=Mohamed Salah breaks goal record as Liverpool blow away Brighton|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB}}</ref> **Real Madrid win their third consecutive Champions League by beating Liverpool.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/may/26/real-madrid-v-liverpool-champions-league-final-2018-live|title=Real Madrid beat Liverpool 3-1 to win Champions League final 2018 – as it happened|last=Smyth|first=Rob|date=2018-05-26|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> [[Atlético Madrid|Atletico Madrid]] become Europa League Champions. Atletico Madrid beat derby rivals Real Madrid to become UEFA Super Cup champions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/global/2018/aug/15/real-madrid-atletico-madrid-european-super-cup-match-report|title=Diego Costa double helps Atlético beat Real Madrid 4-2 in Uefa Super Cup|last=sport|first=Guardian|date=2018-08-15|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-11-18}}</ref> **The [[2018 FIFA World Cup|21st edition FIFA World Cup]] is held in [[Russia]] and is won by [[France national football team|France]] for the second time. The World Cup broke the record for most penalties.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/world-cup-2018/fixtures-and-results/world-cup-breaks-record-for-most-penalties-awarded-37049277.html|title=World Cup breaks record for most penalties awarded - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en}}</ref> **UEFA launches the first edition of the [[UEFA Nations League]] **[[Switzerland]] and [[Lithuania]] hosted respectively the [[UEFA Women's Euro U-19 2018|U-19]] and [[UEFA Women's Euro U-17|U-17]] feminine competitions. The masculine versions of [[UEFA Euro U-19 2018|U-19]] and [[UEFA Euro U-17 2018|U-17]] are hosted by [[Finland]] and [[England]]. These 4 competitions are won by [[Spain]] (feminine: both U-19 and U-17), [[Portugal]] (masculine: U-19) and the [[Netherlands]] (masculine: U-17).
